These testing films are pre-prepped for quick use & can deliver results faster than other methods. That helps speed up the trip from the farm to your fork! üçΩÔ∏è

The test uses the 3M Science of a thin film that can rapidly grow bacteria or mold from a food sample. The number of dots that develop indicates if the food will maintain quality for the rest of its journey. üî¨

Short trip or long, food manufacturers want to know the quality of food when it arrives and if it will stay fresh long enough to reach your plate. A simple test that counts microbes can reveal the answer. üîç

Lighter, more reflective materials can lower roof temps. Like 3M‚Ñ¢ Cool Roofing Granules, which reflect up to 4x more light. They also match the color and curb appeal of traditional shingle materials.
Did you know with cool roofing materials there is a possible -20¬∞F decrease in residential roof temperatures? Cool down without standing out!

When you put a lot of hot roofs together you get the urban heat island effect, where roofs and pavement can make cities over 5¬∞F hotter during the day. It increases energy use by 5-10%, degrades air quality & aggravates heat-related illness.
Standard roofs get a lot of sun & absorb a lot of heat. That can make your home warmer throughout the day & use more energy for air conditioning.
Roofs can reach 150¬∞F or more in the summer. üè†‚òÄÔ∏è
The right roof can make a whole house more efficient without looking like it, thanks to 3M Science.

What‚Äôs next? Signs that are bright and smart. We are testing ‚Äúinvisible‚Äù smart codes that can share precise GPS coordinates & more with self-driving vehicles.
Brighter signs mean better communication. We use the science of millions of microscopic prisms to reflect light directly back to its source, making signs that are even brighter.
However, self-driving buses (and cars) can use this same reflectivity during the day, making it easier to pick them out from the chaos of pedestrians, bicyclists and trees.
Street signs & road markings reflect light to help people see them at night. ‚ö†Ô∏è
They already do. Signs & road markings tell you where to go, but self-driving vehicles also use them- in ways that may surprise you.

@MrsBench214 Our scientist Vasav Sahni says, "The thrill part of it. The thrill that you get from solving problems and getting answers. It's a good drive to keep on learning more."

@MrsBench214 They mostly move around on the non-sticky parts, which are the threads that spin out from the center of the web (but that's just one kind of web -- there are many different architectures).
@MrsLizGonzalez You got it!
@nls4thgrade Living things ARE nature!
@CoachtoLearn That's great to hear! We're glad you're following along.
@_AmandaFry Identifying a need or a problem and figuring out how to meet that need or solve that problem.
@_AmandaFry We like "The Science of Everything" by National Geographic.
@MrsBench214 1902 in Two Harbors, Minnesota. Our first product was sandpaper!
@_AmandaFry For engineer Ken Cox: "It was getting a microscope when I was in 4th grade and it opened up a whole new world of things."
@MrsBench214 Our insulation is used by the garment industry to make coats (we don't actually make coats!)

@_AmandaFry Good question. They stick because of the elements they have under their toes. Those elements are soft and stick to surfaces. They unstick by the way geckos curl their toes -- so they use different motions climbing a tree versus running across the ground.
@CoachtoLearn Very cluknky. Nature does a good job of doing things elegantly. When we mimic nature, things can be done much more simply.
@CarmenGlaister Study, take math and science classes, and find out what interests you.
@CarmenGlaister Everything! Trying new things that have never been done before is really cool.
@CarmenGlaister We think spiders are cool. There's one species that doesn't spin a web -- it makes a lasso to catch male moths. Our team calls it the "cowboy spider!"
@ScienceFrick Great question. Half an hour!
@CoachtoLearn Hi Maria -- We don't make an entire jacket from scratch. One approach is to take an existing down jacket, remove the down and replace it with our experimental materials.

@Kregan26 Hi Mrs. Regan's 4th grade class! We often take a problem and wonder, "How does nature solve it?" We like the goose down example -- geese have good insulation without getting wet. Then understanding how geese do that leads to studying biomimicry.
@ClassCoulter Hi Susan -- It comes from "thin insulation." When it was invented in 1978, it was the thinnest insulation at the time made from synthetic polymeric fibers.

@DoctorCJimenez Hi Corinne -- We often take a problem and wonder, "How does nature solve that?" That's like the goose down example -- geese have good insulation without getting wet. Then understanding how geese do that leads to studying biomimicry.
